Treatment: Treatment includes psychotherapy and antidepressant medications. Lifestyle changes such as regular exercise, healthy diet, and social support improve outcomes. Close monitoring for suicidal thoughts is important.

Treatment depends on the cancer type and stage. Surgery may remove the tumor if detected early. Chemotherapy and radiation therapy are common to kill cancer cells and reduce tumor size. Targeted therapies and immunotherapy can help in advanced cases. Supportive care manages symptoms.

Drugs.Name: Cisplatin
Drugs.Description: Chemotherapy drug that kills cancer cells.

Treatment: Treatment includes surgery (lumpectomy or mastectomy), radiation therapy to destroy remaining cancer cells, chemotherapy to target cancer throughout the body, and hormone therapy if cancer is hormone receptor positive. Targeted therapies may be used based on cancer type.

Surgery removes tumors in early stages. Chemotherapy and radiation therapy reduce recurrence risk and treat advanced disease. Regular screening helps early diagnosis. Lifestyle changes may improve recovery and reduce risk.

Options include active surveillance for low-risk cancer, surgery to remove the prostate, radiation therapy, hormone therapy to reduce testosterone, and chemotherapy for advanced stages. Treatment choice depends on cancer aggressiveness and patient health.

Early bladder cancer is treated with surgical removal of tumors and intravesical therapy where medication is directly placed in the bladder. Advanced disease may require chemotherapy, radiation, or bladder removal surgery. Regular cystoscopy follow-ups are important.

Chemotherapy is the main treatment, sometimes combined with immunotherapy targeting cancer cells. Radiation therapy can be used in localized disease. Stem cell transplantation may be considered for aggressive cases. Treatment is personalized based on lymphoma subtype.

Treatment depends on leukemia type and includes chemotherapy to destroy abnormal blood cells, targeted therapy, and stem cell transplantation. Supportive care treats infections and anemia. Early diagnosis and treatment improve survival.

Drugs.Name: Imatinib
Drugs.Description: Targeted therapy for chronic myeloid leukemia.

Treatment: Surgery offers potential cure in early stages. Chemotherapy and radiation help control tumor growth. Pain management and nutritional support improve quality of life. Due to late diagnosis, prognosis is often poor, so early screening in high-risk patients is important.

Surgery to remove part or all of the thyroid gland is standard. Radioactive iodine therapy destroys remaining cancer cells. Thyroid hormone therapy prevents cancer recurrence and maintains metabolism. Regular follow-up with ultrasound and blood tests is needed.

Treatment includes surgery to remove tumors and chemotherapy to kill cancer cells. Targeted therapies may be added based on tumor genetics. Early diagnosis is challenging, so monitoring symptoms is important for timely intervention.
Treatment involves surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Nutritional support is vital as swallowing becomes difficult. Early detection improves prognosis, but symptoms often appear late.

Surgical removal is primary treatment. In advanced cases, immunotherapy or targeted therapy help control disease spread. Sun protection and regular skin checks are important for prevention and early detection.
Treatment involves surgical removal of affected testicle, chemotherapy, and sometimes radiation therapy. Prognosis is excellent with early treatment. Regular self-examination helps early detection.
Combination of surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy based on tumor location and stage. Smoking and alcohol cessation improves outcomes. Speech therapy aids recovery post-treatment.
Treatment involves surgery to remove the tumor, chemotherapy, and sometimes radiation therapy. Nutritional support and symptom management are essential. Early diagnosis improves survival rates.
Common in children, treatment includes surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, and immunotherapy. Treatment intensity depends on risk category. Supportive care manages symptoms and side effects.
Treatment includes chemotherapy, targeted therapy, and stem cell transplantation. Supportive care treats bone damage and infections. New drugs improve survival significantly.

Treatment may involve watchful waiting in early stages. When needed, chemotherapy, targeted therapies, and immunotherapy are used. Treatment is personalized based on genetic features of leukemia cells.
Highly treatable with chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Stem cell transplantation is used in relapsed cases. Early diagnosis and treatment offer excellent prognosis.

Drugs.Name: ABVD regimen
Drugs.Description: Combination chemotherapy including Adriamycin, Bleomycin, Vinblastine, Dacarbazine.

Treatment: Treatment depends on cancer stage and includes surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy. Early detection via Pap smear improves outcomes. HPV vaccination helps prevent cervical cancer.

Treatment usually involves surgical removal of the gallbladder and surrounding tissues. When surgery isn‚Äôt possible, chemotherapy and radiation therapy can help control the tumor. Pain and nutritional support are important to improve quality of life during treatment.

Drugs.Name: Gemcitabine
Drugs.Description: Chemotherapy drug to slow tumor growth.

Treatment: Treatment includes surgery to remove the tumor or part of the larynx, radiation therapy to destroy cancer cells, and chemotherapy for advanced stages. Voice rehabilitation and swallowing therapy are often part of post-treatment care.
Surgery is the primary treatment to remove tumors. Chemotherapy and radiation therapy may be added depending on the stage. Nutritional support is crucial due to digestive system involvement.
Surgical removal of the affected kidney is the main treatment. Targeted therapies and immunotherapy can be used for advanced cancer to slow progression. Regular imaging is important for follow-up.

Treatment includes surgical removal of the tumor with clear margins, often combined with radiation therapy. Chemotherapy is used in aggressive or advanced cases. Physical therapy helps recovery of function.

Treatment includes surgery to remove as much tumor as possible, followed by radiation therapy and chemotherapy to target remaining cancer cells. Supportive care manages symptoms like seizures and swelling.
Treatment includes surgical removal of tumors from affected glands, hormone replacement therapy, and regular monitoring. Genetic counseling is important due to hereditary nature.
Treatment involves surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy to reduce tumor size and relieve symptoms. Early diagnosis improves options. Palliative care focuses on quality of life.
Surgery to remove the affected testicle is primary treatment. Radiation therapy or chemotherapy may be used depending on stage. Regular follow-up is essential for early detection of recurrence.
